attributes.title: Media trust and news consumption: Evidence from survey and behavioral measures

q1.value: Media trust and news consumption: Evidence from survey and behavioral measures

q2.value: Andrew Guess | Brendan Nyhan | Jason Reifler

q5.value: We acknowledge financial support from Craig Newmark and the Poynter Institute.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study seeks to understand how and why trust in the media is changing in the U.S. and how levels of media trust expressed in surveys correspond to actual information consumption behavior. To examine these questions, we have designed a two-wave public opinion survey on the YouGov Pulse panel that includes independent experimental randomizations in each wave. In addition to collecting survey responses during each of the two waves, we are also passively collecting anonymized individual-level web traffic with users' consent, allowing us to measure their real-world behavior. Overall, our hypotheses and analysis will consist of two primary components: -An observational analysis of descriptive patterns of media trust and information consumption in our survey and behavioral data. -Tests of the effect of our experimental treatments on attitudes toward the media (survey outcomes) and information consumption (behavioral outcomes).

q16.value: Wave 1: Survey evidence of differences in media attitudes To test our hypotheses about news media attitudes, it is first necessary to determine how to best measure them. We have ten post-treatment survey questions that will serve as our dependent variables (plus one additional measure of feelings toward the news media that is only asked post-treatment in wave 2). Using the thematic groupings below, we will examine whether these questions scale together or not using only data from the control condition (which is not affected by the experimental manipulation in wave 1). Trust/confidence in media (general and specific organizations): -News media feeling thermometer (pre-treatment in wave 1; post-treatment in wave 2) -Confidence in people running the press -Confidence and trust in the New York Times, Fox News, and CNN (Economist and Guardian items excluded as relatively unfamiliar/foreign) Press accuracy/bias: -Accuracy of news posted online -Major news organizations fabricate -Does the media deal fairly with all sides or favor one side? Support for press freedom: -Criticism of leaders prevents politicians from doing their job (versus keeps them from doing things that shouldn't be done) -Are journalists an enemy of the people? -Government should be able to prevent publication of coverage it says is biased/inaccurate RQ1: Do measures of media trust and confidence in the press, perceived accuracy or bias, and support for limitations on freedom of the press correspond closely with each other? Based on the results of this analysis, we will construct a composite measures of media attitudes that we will use in the analyses below in addition to specific measures of media trust, perceptions of accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom. The hypotheses of interest below will typically be described as examining "attitudes toward the media" or similar terms, which refers to the composite outcome measure we intend to construct as a result of this analysis. We will also separately estimate effects on the three subscales listed above of media trust, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom specifically for each hypothesis. Further details about how these measures will be constructed will be provided in the statistical analysis section below. Attitudes toward the news media vary widely. Over the last several decades, leading Republican and conservative voices have accused the mainstream media of having a liberal bias. The flow of negative claims about the press have escalated since 2016. Donald Trump has repeatedly attacked the press as "fake news" and accused it of fabrications on the campaign trail and now in the White House. We therefore expect that Republicans, conservatives, and Trump approvers will, on average, express significantly more negative attitudes toward the media than Democrats, liberals, and Trump disapprovers, respectively: H1a: Republicans will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Democrats. Similarly, conservatives will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than either liberals or moderates and Trump approvers will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Trump disapprovers. We also expect that differences in perceptions of media bias and and trust between Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives, and Trump approvers and Trump disapprovers will vary by respondents' levels of political knowledge: H1b: The gap between Republicans and Democrats in attitudes toward the media will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. Similarly, the gap between liberals and conservatives and between Trump approvers and disapprovers will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. (We will also conduct a descriptive analysis of how attitudes toward the media vary over time when comparing our survey measures of these attitudes to those in other surveys that have used identical question wording. Given that our media attitude measures are measured post-treatment, we will verify that these findings hold using only respondents in our control condition.) Wave 1: Survey data/behavioral data We will conduct descriptive analyses of the extent that self-reports of news consumption relate to actual news consumption and the relationship between media trust and news consumption: RQ2a: To what extent are self-reports of outlet-specific news consumption correlated with actual consumption of news from those outlets? RQ2b: To what extent are attitudes toward the news media correlated with mainstream news consumption? RQ2c: To what extent is outlet-specific trust correlated with consumption of news from those outlets? Waves 1 and 2: Experimental effects on media attitudes measured in surveys In the first survey wave, we embed an experiment that uses random assignment to test the effects of messages about the media on attitudes toward the media. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment conditions. In one condition, respondents are shown a news article about a highly salient media error - a story by CNN erroneously linking a Trump transition team member (Anthony Scaramucci) to the ongoing Russia investigation, which resulted in the responsible employees leaving the news network. A second condition instead tests the effect of Donald Trump attacking the media; in that condition, respondents are shown an article in which Trump calls reporting on the Russia investigation "fake news." In the third condition, respondents are shown a placebo message about the Russia investigation, mentioning it in a similar manner to the first two conditions without mentioning either the CNN error or Trump's attacks on the media. Comparisons to this condition will allow us to isolate the effect of the first two treatments from the effect of reminders of Trump and the Russia investigation. Finally, respondents who were randomized into the control condition were shown an unrelated article about using sauces in cooking. We expect to observe directionally motivated reasoning in response to the negative information about the press. The messages about a media error and attacks on the media should have a greater effect on Trump approvers and Republicans (for whom they are more likely to be attitude-consistent) than among Trump disapprovers and Democrats, respectively. Our hypotheses and research questions about the experiment are the following: H2a: The media attack and media error conditions will both worsen attitudes toward the press among Trump approvers and Republicans (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2b: The media error condition will worsen attitudes toward the press and toward CNN specifically for all respondents (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2c: The media attack condition will worsen attitudes toward the press for all respondents (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2d: The media attack and media error conditions will worsen attitudes toward the press more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats (compared to the Russia placebo condition). We expect to observe this difference specifically for trust in CNN in the media error condition. Given the potential for backlash effects to a message from a disfavored source, we also propose the following research question for the response to the media attack condition among Trump disapprovers and Democrats: RQ3a: Will the media attack condition improve attitudes toward the media among Trump disapprovers and Democrats (compared to the Russia placebo condition)? We do not have strong theoretical expectations about the difference between the media attack and media error conditions but intend to evaluate this quantity. We therefore propose it as a research question: RQ3b: Will the media attack or media error condition worsen attitudes toward the press more for the full sample and for Trump approvers, Republicans, Trump disapprovers, and/or Democrats? We expect that the above hypotheses will hold with the same DVs in the second wave (persistence). We will test H2a/H2b/H2c/H2d and RQ3a/RQ3b again in wave 2 if we do not observe evidence of differential attrition in wave 2 participation (though this does not rule out post-treatment bias - see Montgomery, Nyhan and Torres: http://www.dartmouth.edu/~nyhan/post-treatment-bias.pdf). Details of how these tests will be conducted are provided below. Waves 1 and 2: Experimental effects on behavioral measures of information consumption We also expect that the media attack and error messages will have a significant effect on news consumption in the immediate aftermath of the wave 1 experimental manipulation: H3a: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce consumption of mainstream news sources and increase consumption of non-mainstream news sources among Trump approvers and Republicans in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3b: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce consumption of mainstream news sources among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3c: The media attack and media error conditions will increase consumption of non-mainstream news sources among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled; see below.) H3d: The media error condition will reduce consumption of CNN among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3e: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce mainstream news consumption more and increase non-mainstream news consumption more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3f: The media error condition will reduce consumption of CNN more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled for the mainstream and non-mainstream news consumption outcomes; see below.) Waves 1 and 2: Information consumption and media attitudes in specific controversies We will also conduct more focused tests of information consumption on two issues: the number of refugees that should be admitted to the United States and Roy Moore, the Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate in the Alabama special election. To further explore the relationship between media attitudes and behavior, we will first use the experiment embedded in wave 2, which encourages a random subset of participants to search for information about the issue of admitting refugees to the United States. As a manipulation check, we will first verify that respondents assigned to receive the refugee encouragement will be more likely to search for information about the refugee crisis in the week after Wave 2. If the manipulation is successful, we will test the following hypotheses: H4a: The effect of the refugee encouragement treatment on consumption of information about the refugee crisis from mainstream news and information sources will be greater for respondents with more positive attitudes toward the media compared to respondents with less positive attitudes toward the media. H4b: The effect of the refugee encouragement treatment on consumption of information about the refugee crisis from non-mainstream news and information sources will be greater for respondents with less positive attitudes toward the media compared to respondents with more positive attitudes toward the media. (Importantly, H4a and H4b are separate hypotheses because the amount of mainstream and non-mainstream news consumed are separate quantities and may not be strict substitutes.) H4c: In the week after Wave 2, respondents in the refugee encouragement treatment who were previously randomized into the media attack and media error conditions will be more likely to view information about the refugee crisis from non-mainstream and less likely to view information from mainstream news and information sources. (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect; see below.) Second, we will examine information consumption about Moore. On November 9, 2017, The Washington Post posted a story online in which credible accusations were made that Moore had multiple sexual encounters with minors while he was in his 30s. This story caused a major scandal and eventually led the national Republican Party to cut off Moore from campaign funding. In the meantime, an intensive campaign was conducted, via social media and other channels, to discredit the Post's reporting. (Breitbart was heavily involved in this campaign.) We will explore the effect of the unanticipated Moore scandal, which began once our study was already in the field, on attitudes toward the media in Wave 2 and behavioral measures of information consumption. H5a: Trump disapprovers and Democrats were more likely to read Post coverage of the Roy Moore controversy than Trump approvers and Republicans, respectively. We expect the converse to be true for Breitbart coverage of Moore. H5b: Trump approvers and Republicans consumed fewer Post articles, and more Breitbart articles, after the story was published compared to before. We expect the converse to be true for Trump disapprovers and Democrats and also expect that the difference in consumption change by outlet between groups will be significant. H5c: Respondents who were previously randomized into the media attack and media error conditions were less likely to consume Washington Post coverage of the Moore controversy (compared to Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled for the mainstream and non-mainstream news consumption outcomes; see below.) RQ4: Will Trump approvers and Republicans who complete wave 2 surveys after the Washington Post story about Moore was published express relatively more negative attitudes toward the media compared to those who completed it before publication?

q17.value: As discussed above, our hypothesis are tested using data collected from a two-wave public opinion survey with embedded experiments where we also collect the web traffic data on a person's computer. We will examine our research questions and hypotheses using responses to survey questions and online behavioral data. The outcome measures will be coded as specified below. We will then conduct the statistical analyses described below. Randomization approach Respondents will be randomized by YouGov with equal probability in wave 1 to one of four conditions: a control condition in which they view an unrelated message, a placebo condition in which they read a story about the Russia investigation with no errors or attacks on the media, a media attack condition in which they read a story about the Russia investigation in which Donald Trump denounces the media, and a media error condition in which they read a story describing the retraction of an unsupported news article about the Russia investigation. Respondents will be independently randomized by YouGov with equal probability in wave 2 to one of two conditions: a control condition or to an information-seeking stimulus that seeks to induce respondents to search for more information about the issue of admitting refugees to the United States. Respondents, data collection and blinding We are conducting this study using a YouGov Pulse panel of US residents age 18 or older, which is recruited and maintained by YouGov. We expect this sample, which will be collected on the YouGov platform, to consist of approximately 2100 participants in wave 1 and 1500 participants in wave 2. Respondents are blind to condition. The data, which are anonymized, will include survey data and online behavioral data from respondents willing to install tracking software. The online tracking panel is currently branded as YouGov Pulse. Panelists are recruited from YouGov's traditional participant pool via incentives. The data to be used for this study covers approximately three weeks of web traffic - one week prior to the first survey, one week between surveys, and one week after the second survey. The software tracks web traffic (minus passwords and financial transactions) for all browsers installed on a user's computer and can be uninstalled at any time. Users provide full consent to download and install the software and identifying information is not collected. Interventions and dates of administration Invitations to participate in wave 1 of the study began to be sent on November 1, 2017. Respondents will be invited to complete wave 2 one week after completing wave 1. Data collection by YouGov will continue until the number of respondents meets the target sample size. Termination of data collection will be determined by YouGov, not the researchers, and will be decided blind to outcomes. The researchers will remain blind to the data until data collection is complete and this preregistration is filed. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All U.S. residents age 18 or older are eligible to participate. Participants must be members of the YouGov Pulse panel to be selected for inclusion. Primary and secondary outcome measures We describe the coding of survey and behavioral outcome measures below. In some cases, we will combine multiple measures to construct composite outcome measures. In those cases, we will use the procedures described in the statistical analysis section of this preregistration. Coding of raw outcome measures: [wave 1] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person or institution. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don't care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate them. (randomize order) -The news media [0-100] In general, how much trust and confidence do you have in the mass media – such as newspapers, TV and radio – when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately, and fairly? -A great deal [4] -A fair amount [3] -Not very much [2] -None at all [1] How accurate, do you think, is the news posted online by news organizations? -Very accurate [4] -Somewhat accurate [3] -Not too accurate [2] -Not at all accurate [1] As far as the people running the press are concerned, would you say you have a great deal of confidence, only some confidence, or hardly any confidence at all in them? -A great deal of confidence [3] -Only some confidence [2] -Hardly any confidence at all [1] Some people think that by criticizing leaders, news organizations keep political leaders from doing their job. Others think that such criticism is worth it because it keeps political leaders from doing things that should not be done. Which position is closer to your opinion? -Keep political leaders from doing their job [0] -Keep political leaders from doing things that shouldn't be done [1] In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think that news organizations deal fairly with all sides, or do they tend to favor one side? -Deal fairly with all sides [1] -Tend to favor one side [0] [if "tend to favor" selected above] In your opinion, which side do news organizations tend to favor? -Conservatives -Liberals [We will construct a three-point measure of perceived directional bias using responses to the two questions above where 1=perceived conservative bias (tend to favor one side/conservatives), 2=deal fairly with all sides, and 3=perceived liberal bias (tend to favor one side/liberals).] Based on what you know, how often do you believe the nation's major news organizations fabricate news stories about the President? -Never [5] -Once in a while [4] -About half the time [3] -Most of the time [2] -All the time [1] Are journalists today an enemy of the American people? -Yes [0] -No [1] Do you think the government should or should not be able to stop a news media outlet from publishing a story that government officials say is biased or inaccurate? -Should be able [0] -Should not be able [1] Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly. If you are not familiar with the source, please select don't know. -The New York Times -The Economist -The Guardian -Fox News -CNN Response options: -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] -Don't know [treated as missing data] [wave 2] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person or institution. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don't care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate them. (randomize order) -The news media [0-100] In general, how much trust and confidence do you have in the mass media – such as newspapers, TV and radio – when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately, and fairly? -A great deal [4] -A fair amount [3] -Not very much [2] -None at all [1] How accurate, do you think, is the news posted online by news organizations? -Very accurate [4] -Somewhat accurate [3] -Not too accurate [2] -Not at all accurate [1] As far as the people running the press are concerned, would you say you have a great deal of confidence, only some confidence, or hardly any confidence at all in them? -A great deal of confidence [3] -Only some confidence [2] -Hardly any confidence at all [1] Some people think that by criticizing leaders, news organizations keep political leaders from doing their job. Others think that such criticism is worth it because it keeps political leaders from doing things that should not be done. Which position is closer to your opinion? -Keep political leaders from doing their job [0] -Keep political leaders from doing things that shouldn't be done [1] In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think that news organizations deal fairly with all sides, or do they tend to favor one side? -Deal fairly with all sides [1] -Tend to favor one side [0] [if "tend to favor" selected above] In your opinion, which side do news organizations tend to favor? -Conservatives -Liberals [We will construct a three-point measure of perceived directional bias using responses to the two questions above where 1=perceived conservative bias (tend to favor one side/conservatives), 2=deal fairly with all sides, and 3=perceived liberal bias (tend to favor one side/liberals).] Based on what you know, how often do you believe the nation's major news organizations fabricate news stories about the President? -Never [5] -Once in a while [4] -About half the time [3] -Most of the time [2] -All the time [1] Are journalists today an enemy of the American people? -Yes [0] -No [1] Do you think the government should or should not be able to stop a news media outlet from publishing a story that government officials say is biased or inaccurate? -Should be able [0] -Should not be able [1] Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly. If you are not familiar with the source, please select don't know. -The New York Times -The Economist -The Guardian -Fox News -CNN Response options: -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] -Don't know [treated as missing data] Note: For consistency, all dependent variables are coded such that higher values indicate more positive attitudes toward the media. However, we may reverse the direction of coding for expositional reasons when it is more intuitive for higher values to indicate more negative perceptions (e.g., greater perceptions of bias). We will assess the dimensionality of the 11 post-treatment variables measuring attitudes toward the media using factor analysis with these variables. We will first estimate a composite measure of media attitudes using the loadings from the first dimension of a factor analysis estimated on the control group in each wave. We will then use those loadings to calculate the composite media attitude score for all respondents. As discussed above, the composite measure includes questions that tap subtle but important differences in dimensions of attitudes towards the media and the press (attitudes about trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom). We will therefore also estimate separate factor scores for each subscale (trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom) using an identical procedure to the main composite measure. (All factor analysis will be estimated using principal-components factor analysis with a varimax rotation.) (We will confirm that the results are similar in MPLUS using the ESEM WLSVM estimator to verify that findings are consistent between data treated as continuous and data treated as categorical.) Behavioral outcome measure coding: We will measure visits to the websites of the outlets listed in the question "Which of these websites have you visited or used in the past week for news, if any?" and in "Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly." Depending on the research question or hypothesis of interest, the time period of measurement may vary (e.g., the full period observed in the data, the period before wave 1, the period after wave 1, the period after wave 2, etc.). We will specify this time period in the statistical analysis section below. We will code news and information websites as "mainstream" if any of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (see above; based on behavioral data from a previous YouGov Pulse study) and are not affiliated with a particular political party or ideology; -had at least 5 million total unique monthly visits in our 2015 comScore data and ideology slant scores (Bakshy et al. 2015) between -0.55 and 0.55 inclusive and are based in the U.S.; -it is a Wikipedia article; -it is associated with one of the broadcast news networks (ABC, CBS, or NBC); -it is WSJ.com (omitted from our survey question because it is paywalled, but people may choose WSJ articles from a Google search) -it is one of the major fact-checking national organizations (PolitiFact, Snopes, or Factcheck.org; the Washington Post Fact Checker is excluded because it is part of the Washington Post, which is already a qualifying media outlet under the criteria above) The list is: abcnews.go.com, aol.com, buzzfeed.com, cbsnews.com, chicagotribune.com, cnbc.com, cnn.com, examiner.com, factcheck.org, fivethirtyeight.com, latimes.com, msn.com, nbcnews.com, nydailynews.com, nypost.com, nytimes.com, politico.com, politifact.com, realclearpolitics.com, snopes.com, theatlantic.com, thedailybeast.com, time.com, usnews.com, washingtonpost.com, wikipedia.org, wsj.com We count news and information websites as "non-mainstream" if they are not on the mainstream list above and either of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (which was based on traffic from a previous YouGov Pulse study); -they are classified as focusing on "hard news" topics by Bakshy et al. (2015) but fall outside the [-0.55, 0.55] ideological range (out of -2 to 2) The set of qualifying websites in this set includes Breitbart, Daily Kos, Fox News, Huffington Post, Talking Points Memo, and The Blaze. We will analyze web visit data (including scraped contents of pages visited) from respondents for the seven days after they each complete the Wave 2 survey to code for whether or not they searched for information about refugees. Respondents will be coded as having done so (in both binary and count terms) if their web visit data meet any of the following criteria: -Contain any Google searches with search terms including "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" -Pages containing the words "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" -URLs containing the words "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" We will measure visits to the Washington Post and Breitbart before and after the Roy Moore controversy as well as visits to pages containing the words "Roy Moore" after the controversy began (we assume all coverage published during the study period after the controversy began at least referenced it). We will consider effects on total webpages visited from mainstream and non-mainstream news and information sources using the criteria described above (we expect that most people will visit at least one website in both categories during the study period and thus exclude a binary measure) and both a binary and count measure for specific behavioral information exposure and search measures (Roy Moore and refugees) using the criteria defined above. Duplicate visits to webpages will not be counted if they are successive (i.e., a page that was reloaded after first opening it). URLs are cleaned of referrer information and other parameters before de-duplication. Statistical analyses All models will be estimated using ordinary least squares with robust standard errors. We will estimate all experimental models in the paper using the control condition as a baseline and present those in the main text or the appendix, but to facilitate reader understanding of placebo versus treatment differences we may report models using the Russia investigation placebo condition as the baseline and excluding the control condition (results will be identical). We will compute the appropriate linear combinations of coefficients to test the relevant hypotheses (e.g., mediaerror-russiaplacebo when the control condition is the excluded category). registration_responses.q1: Media trust and news consumption: Evidence from survey and behavioral measures
registration_responses.q2: Andrew Guess | Brendan Nyhan | Jason Reifler
registration_responses.q5: We acknowledge financial support from Craig Newmark and the Poynter Institute.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This study seeks to understand how and why trust in the media is changing in the U.S. and how levels of media trust expressed in surveys correspond to actual information consumption behavior. To examine these questions, we have designed a two-wave public opinion survey on the YouGov Pulse panel that includes independent experimental randomizations in each wave. In addition to collecting survey responses during each of the two waves, we are also passively collecting anonymized individual-level web traffic with users' consent, allowing us to measure their real-world behavior. Overall, our hypotheses and analysis will consist of two primary components: -An observational analysis of descriptive patterns of media trust and information consumption in our survey and behavioral data. -Tests of the effect of our experimental treatments on attitudes toward the media (survey outcomes) and information consumption (behavioral outcomes).
registration_responses.q16: Wave 1: Survey evidence of differences in media attitudes To test our hypotheses about news media attitudes, it is first necessary to determine how to best measure them. We have ten post-treatment survey questions that will serve as our dependent variables (plus one additional measure of feelings toward the news media that is only asked post-treatment in wave 2). Using the thematic groupings below, we will examine whether these questions scale together or not using only data from the control condition (which is not affected by the experimental manipulation in wave 1). Trust/confidence in media (general and specific organizations): -News media feeling thermometer (pre-treatment in wave 1; post-treatment in wave 2) -Confidence in people running the press -Confidence and trust in the New York Times, Fox News, and CNN (Economist and Guardian items excluded as relatively unfamiliar/foreign) Press accuracy/bias: -Accuracy of news posted online -Major news organizations fabricate -Does the media deal fairly with all sides or favor one side? Support for press freedom: -Criticism of leaders prevents politicians from doing their job (versus keeps them from doing things that shouldn't be done) -Are journalists an enemy of the people? -Government should be able to prevent publication of coverage it says is biased/inaccurate RQ1: Do measures of media trust and confidence in the press, perceived accuracy or bias, and support for limitations on freedom of the press correspond closely with each other? Based on the results of this analysis, we will construct a composite measures of media attitudes that we will use in the analyses below in addition to specific measures of media trust, perceptions of accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom. The hypotheses of interest below will typically be described as examining "attitudes toward the media" or similar terms, which refers to the composite outcome measure we intend to construct as a result of this analysis. We will also separately estimate effects on the three subscales listed above of media trust, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom specifically for each hypothesis. Further details about how these measures will be constructed will be provided in the statistical analysis section below. Attitudes toward the news media vary widely. Over the last several decades, leading Republican and conservative voices have accused the mainstream media of having a liberal bias. The flow of negative claims about the press have escalated since 2016. Donald Trump has repeatedly attacked the press as "fake news" and accused it of fabrications on the campaign trail and now in the White House. We therefore expect that Republicans, conservatives, and Trump approvers will, on average, express significantly more negative attitudes toward the media than Democrats, liberals, and Trump disapprovers, respectively: H1a: Republicans will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Democrats. Similarly, conservatives will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than either liberals or moderates and Trump approvers will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Trump disapprovers. We also expect that differences in perceptions of media bias and and trust between Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives, and Trump approvers and Trump disapprovers will vary by respondents' levels of political knowledge: H1b: The gap between Republicans and Democrats in attitudes toward the media will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. Similarly, the gap between liberals and conservatives and between Trump approvers and disapprovers will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. (We will also conduct a descriptive analysis of how attitudes toward the media vary over time when comparing our survey measures of these attitudes to those in other surveys that have used identical question wording. Given that our media attitude measures are measured post-treatment, we will verify that these findings hold using only respondents in our control condition.) Wave 1: Survey data/behavioral data We will conduct descriptive analyses of the extent that self-reports of news consumption relate to actual news consumption and the relationship between media trust and news consumption: RQ2a: To what extent are self-reports of outlet-specific news consumption correlated with actual consumption of news from those outlets? RQ2b: To what extent are attitudes toward the news media correlated with mainstream news consumption? RQ2c: To what extent is outlet-specific trust correlated with consumption of news from those outlets? Waves 1 and 2: Experimental effects on media attitudes measured in surveys In the first survey wave, we embed an experiment that uses random assignment to test the effects of messages about the media on attitudes toward the media. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment conditions. In one condition, respondents are shown a news article about a highly salient media error - a story by CNN erroneously linking a Trump transition team member (Anthony Scaramucci) to the ongoing Russia investigation, which resulted in the responsible employees leaving the news network. A second condition instead tests the effect of Donald Trump attacking the media; in that condition, respondents are shown an article in which Trump calls reporting on the Russia investigation "fake news." In the third condition, respondents are shown a placebo message about the Russia investigation, mentioning it in a similar manner to the first two conditions without mentioning either the CNN error or Trump's attacks on the media. Comparisons to this condition will allow us to isolate the effect of the first two treatments from the effect of reminders of Trump and the Russia investigation. Finally, respondents who were randomized into the control condition were shown an unrelated article about using sauces in cooking. We expect to observe directionally motivated reasoning in response to the negative information about the press. The messages about a media error and attacks on the media should have a greater effect on Trump approvers and Republicans (for whom they are more likely to be attitude-consistent) than among Trump disapprovers and Democrats, respectively. Our hypotheses and research questions about the experiment are the following: H2a: The media attack and media error conditions will both worsen attitudes toward the press among Trump approvers and Republicans (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2b: The media error condition will worsen attitudes toward the press and toward CNN specifically for all respondents (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2c: The media attack condition will worsen attitudes toward the press for all respondents (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H2d: The media attack and media error conditions will worsen attitudes toward the press more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats (compared to the Russia placebo condition). We expect to observe this difference specifically for trust in CNN in the media error condition. Given the potential for backlash effects to a message from a disfavored source, we also propose the following research question for the response to the media attack condition among Trump disapprovers and Democrats: RQ3a: Will the media attack condition improve attitudes toward the media among Trump disapprovers and Democrats (compared to the Russia placebo condition)? We do not have strong theoretical expectations about the difference between the media attack and media error conditions but intend to evaluate this quantity. We therefore propose it as a research question: RQ3b: Will the media attack or media error condition worsen attitudes toward the press more for the full sample and for Trump approvers, Republicans, Trump disapprovers, and/or Democrats? We expect that the above hypotheses will hold with the same DVs in the second wave (persistence). We will test H2a/H2b/H2c/H2d and RQ3a/RQ3b again in wave 2 if we do not observe evidence of differential attrition in wave 2 participation (though this does not rule out post-treatment bias - see Montgomery, Nyhan and Torres: http://www.dartmouth.edu/~nyhan/post-treatment-bias.pdf). Details of how these tests will be conducted are provided below. Waves 1 and 2: Experimental effects on behavioral measures of information consumption We also expect that the media attack and error messages will have a significant effect on news consumption in the immediate aftermath of the wave 1 experimental manipulation: H3a: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce consumption of mainstream news sources and increase consumption of non-mainstream news sources among Trump approvers and Republicans in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3b: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce consumption of mainstream news sources among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3c: The media attack and media error conditions will increase consumption of non-mainstream news sources among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled; see below.) H3d: The media error condition will reduce consumption of CNN among all respondents in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3e: The media attack and media error conditions will reduce mainstream news consumption more and increase non-mainstream news consumption more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). H3f: The media error condition will reduce consumption of CNN more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats in the week following treatment (compared to the Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled for the mainstream and non-mainstream news consumption outcomes; see below.) Waves 1 and 2: Information consumption and media attitudes in specific controversies We will also conduct more focused tests of information consumption on two issues: the number of refugees that should be admitted to the United States and Roy Moore, the Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate in the Alabama special election. To further explore the relationship between media attitudes and behavior, we will first use the experiment embedded in wave 2, which encourages a random subset of participants to search for information about the issue of admitting refugees to the United States. As a manipulation check, we will first verify that respondents assigned to receive the refugee encouragement will be more likely to search for information about the refugee crisis in the week after Wave 2. If the manipulation is successful, we will test the following hypotheses: H4a: The effect of the refugee encouragement treatment on consumption of information about the refugee crisis from mainstream news and information sources will be greater for respondents with more positive attitudes toward the media compared to respondents with less positive attitudes toward the media. H4b: The effect of the refugee encouragement treatment on consumption of information about the refugee crisis from non-mainstream news and information sources will be greater for respondents with less positive attitudes toward the media compared to respondents with more positive attitudes toward the media. (Importantly, H4a and H4b are separate hypotheses because the amount of mainstream and non-mainstream news consumed are separate quantities and may not be strict substitutes.) H4c: In the week after Wave 2, respondents in the refugee encouragement treatment who were previously randomized into the media attack and media error conditions will be more likely to view information about the refugee crisis from non-mainstream and less likely to view information from mainstream news and information sources. (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect; see below.) Second, we will examine information consumption about Moore. On November 9, 2017, The Washington Post posted a story online in which credible accusations were made that Moore had multiple sexual encounters with minors while he was in his 30s. This story caused a major scandal and eventually led the national Republican Party to cut off Moore from campaign funding. In the meantime, an intensive campaign was conducted, via social media and other channels, to discredit the Post's reporting. (Breitbart was heavily involved in this campaign.) We will explore the effect of the unanticipated Moore scandal, which began once our study was already in the field, on attitudes toward the media in Wave 2 and behavioral measures of information consumption. H5a: Trump disapprovers and Democrats were more likely to read Post coverage of the Roy Moore controversy than Trump approvers and Republicans, respectively. We expect the converse to be true for Breitbart coverage of Moore. H5b: Trump approvers and Republicans consumed fewer Post articles, and more Breitbart articles, after the story was published compared to before. We expect the converse to be true for Trump disapprovers and Democrats and also expect that the difference in consumption change by outlet between groups will be significant. H5c: Respondents who were previously randomized into the media attack and media error conditions were less likely to consume Washington Post coverage of the Moore controversy (compared to Russia placebo condition). (To maximize statistical power for detecting behavioral change, we will test both the individual effect of each treatment as well as their combined effect when pooled for the mainstream and non-mainstream news consumption outcomes; see below.) RQ4: Will Trump approvers and Republicans who complete wave 2 surveys after the Washington Post story about Moore was published express relatively more negative attitudes toward the media compared to those who completed it before publication?
registration_responses.q17: As discussed above, our hypothesis are tested using data collected from a two-wave public opinion survey with embedded experiments where we also collect the web traffic data on a person's computer. We will examine our research questions and hypotheses using responses to survey questions and online behavioral data. The outcome measures will be coded as specified below. We will then conduct the statistical analyses described below. Randomization approach Respondents will be randomized by YouGov with equal probability in wave 1 to one of four conditions: a control condition in which they view an unrelated message, a placebo condition in which they read a story about the Russia investigation with no errors or attacks on the media, a media attack condition in which they read a story about the Russia investigation in which Donald Trump denounces the media, and a media error condition in which they read a story describing the retraction of an unsupported news article about the Russia investigation. Respondents will be independently randomized by YouGov with equal probability in wave 2 to one of two conditions: a control condition or to an information-seeking stimulus that seeks to induce respondents to search for more information about the issue of admitting refugees to the United States. Respondents, data collection and blinding We are conducting this study using a YouGov Pulse panel of US residents age 18 or older, which is recruited and maintained by YouGov. We expect this sample, which will be collected on the YouGov platform, to consist of approximately 2100 participants in wave 1 and 1500 participants in wave 2. Respondents are blind to condition. The data, which are anonymized, will include survey data and online behavioral data from respondents willing to install tracking software. The online tracking panel is currently branded as YouGov Pulse. Panelists are recruited from YouGov's traditional participant pool via incentives. The data to be used for this study covers approximately three weeks of web traffic - one week prior to the first survey, one week between surveys, and one week after the second survey. The software tracks web traffic (minus passwords and financial transactions) for all browsers installed on a user's computer and can be uninstalled at any time. Users provide full consent to download and install the software and identifying information is not collected. Interventions and dates of administration Invitations to participate in wave 1 of the study began to be sent on November 1, 2017. Respondents will be invited to complete wave 2 one week after completing wave 1. Data collection by YouGov will continue until the number of respondents meets the target sample size. Termination of data collection will be determined by YouGov, not the researchers, and will be decided blind to outcomes. The researchers will remain blind to the data until data collection is complete and this preregistration is filed. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All U.S. residents age 18 or older are eligible to participate. Participants must be members of the YouGov Pulse panel to be selected for inclusion. Primary and secondary outcome measures We describe the coding of survey and behavioral outcome measures below. In some cases, we will combine multiple measures to construct composite outcome measures. In those cases, we will use the procedures described in the statistical analysis section of this preregistration. Coding of raw outcome measures: [wave 1] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person or institution. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don't care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate them. (randomize order) -The news media [0-100] In general, how much trust and confidence do you have in the mass media – such as newspapers, TV and radio – when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately, and fairly? -A great deal [4] -A fair amount [3] -Not very much [2] -None at all [1] How accurate, do you think, is the news posted online by news organizations? -Very accurate [4] -Somewhat accurate [3] -Not too accurate [2] -Not at all accurate [1] As far as the people running the press are concerned, would you say you have a great deal of confidence, only some confidence, or hardly any confidence at all in them? -A great deal of confidence [3] -Only some confidence [2] -Hardly any confidence at all [1] Some people think that by criticizing leaders, news organizations keep political leaders from doing their job. Others think that such criticism is worth it because it keeps political leaders from doing things that should not be done. Which position is closer to your opinion? -Keep political leaders from doing their job [0] -Keep political leaders from doing things that shouldn't be done [1] In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think that news organizations deal fairly with all sides, or do they tend to favor one side? -Deal fairly with all sides [1] -Tend to favor one side [0] [if "tend to favor" selected above] In your opinion, which side do news organizations tend to favor? -Conservatives -Liberals [We will construct a three-point measure of perceived directional bias using responses to the two questions above where 1=perceived conservative bias (tend to favor one side/conservatives), 2=deal fairly with all sides, and 3=perceived liberal bias (tend to favor one side/liberals).] Based on what you know, how often do you believe the nation's major news organizations fabricate news stories about the President? -Never [5] -Once in a while [4] -About half the time [3] -Most of the time [2] -All the time [1] Are journalists today an enemy of the American people? -Yes [0] -No [1] Do you think the government should or should not be able to stop a news media outlet from publishing a story that government officials say is biased or inaccurate? -Should be able [0] -Should not be able [1] Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly. If you are not familiar with the source, please select don't know. -The New York Times -The Economist -The Guardian -Fox News -CNN Response options: -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] -Don't know [treated as missing data] [wave 2] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person or institution. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don't care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate them. (randomize order) -The news media [0-100] In general, how much trust and confidence do you have in the mass media – such as newspapers, TV and radio – when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately, and fairly? -A great deal [4] -A fair amount [3] -Not very much [2] -None at all [1] How accurate, do you think, is the news posted online by news organizations? -Very accurate [4] -Somewhat accurate [3] -Not too accurate [2] -Not at all accurate [1] As far as the people running the press are concerned, would you say you have a great deal of confidence, only some confidence, or hardly any confidence at all in them? -A great deal of confidence [3] -Only some confidence [2] -Hardly any confidence at all [1] Some people think that by criticizing leaders, news organizations keep political leaders from doing their job. Others think that such criticism is worth it because it keeps political leaders from doing things that should not be done. Which position is closer to your opinion? -Keep political leaders from doing their job [0] -Keep political leaders from doing things that shouldn't be done [1] In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think that news organizations deal fairly with all sides, or do they tend to favor one side? -Deal fairly with all sides [1] -Tend to favor one side [0] [if "tend to favor" selected above] In your opinion, which side do news organizations tend to favor? -Conservatives -Liberals [We will construct a three-point measure of perceived directional bias using responses to the two questions above where 1=perceived conservative bias (tend to favor one side/conservatives), 2=deal fairly with all sides, and 3=perceived liberal bias (tend to favor one side/liberals).] Based on what you know, how often do you believe the nation's major news organizations fabricate news stories about the President? -Never [5] -Once in a while [4] -About half the time [3] -Most of the time [2] -All the time [1] Are journalists today an enemy of the American people? -Yes [0] -No [1] Do you think the government should or should not be able to stop a news media outlet from publishing a story that government officials say is biased or inaccurate? -Should be able [0] -Should not be able [1] Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly. If you are not familiar with the source, please select don't know. -The New York Times -The Economist -The Guardian -Fox News -CNN Response options: -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] -Don't know [treated as missing data] Note: For consistency, all dependent variables are coded such that higher values indicate more positive attitudes toward the media. However, we may reverse the direction of coding for expositional reasons when it is more intuitive for higher values to indicate more negative perceptions (e.g., greater perceptions of bias). We will assess the dimensionality of the 11 post-treatment variables measuring attitudes toward the media using factor analysis with these variables. We will first estimate a composite measure of media attitudes using the loadings from the first dimension of a factor analysis estimated on the control group in each wave. We will then use those loadings to calculate the composite media attitude score for all respondents. As discussed above, the composite measure includes questions that tap subtle but important differences in dimensions of attitudes towards the media and the press (attitudes about trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom). We will therefore also estimate separate factor scores for each subscale (trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom) using an identical procedure to the main composite measure. (All factor analysis will be estimated using principal-components factor analysis with a varimax rotation.) (We will confirm that the results are similar in MPLUS using the ESEM WLSVM estimator to verify that findings are consistent between data treated as continuous and data treated as categorical.) Behavioral outcome measure coding: We will measure visits to the websites of the outlets listed in the question "Which of these websites have you visited or used in the past week for news, if any?" and in "Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly." Depending on the research question or hypothesis of interest, the time period of measurement may vary (e.g., the full period observed in the data, the period before wave 1, the period after wave 1, the period after wave 2, etc.). We will specify this time period in the statistical analysis section below. We will code news and information websites as "mainstream" if any of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (see above; based on behavioral data from a previous YouGov Pulse study) and are not affiliated with a particular political party or ideology; -had at least 5 million total unique monthly visits in our 2015 comScore data and ideology slant scores (Bakshy et al. 2015) between -0.55 and 0.55 inclusive and are based in the U.S.; -it is a Wikipedia article; -it is associated with one of the broadcast news networks (ABC, CBS, or NBC); -it is WSJ.com (omitted from our survey question because it is paywalled, but people may choose WSJ articles from a Google search) -it is one of the major fact-checking national organizations (PolitiFact, Snopes, or Factcheck.org; the Washington Post Fact Checker is excluded because it is part of the Washington Post, which is already a qualifying media outlet under the criteria above) The list is: abcnews.go.com, aol.com, buzzfeed.com, cbsnews.com, chicagotribune.com, cnbc.com, cnn.com, examiner.com, factcheck.org, fivethirtyeight.com, latimes.com, msn.com, nbcnews.com, nydailynews.com, nypost.com, nytimes.com, politico.com, politifact.com, realclearpolitics.com, snopes.com, theatlantic.com, thedailybeast.com, time.com, usnews.com, washingtonpost.com, wikipedia.org, wsj.com We count news and information websites as "non-mainstream" if they are not on the mainstream list above and either of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (which was based on traffic from a previous YouGov Pulse study); -they are classified as focusing on "hard news" topics by Bakshy et al. (2015) but fall outside the [-0.55, 0.55] ideological range (out of -2 to 2) The set of qualifying websites in this set includes Breitbart, Daily Kos, Fox News, Huffington Post, Talking Points Memo, and The Blaze. We will analyze web visit data (including scraped contents of pages visited) from respondents for the seven days after they each complete the Wave 2 survey to code for whether or not they searched for information about refugees. Respondents will be coded as having done so (in both binary and count terms) if their web visit data meet any of the following criteria: -Contain any Google searches with search terms including "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" -Pages containing the words "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" -URLs containing the words "refug*", "syria", or "migr*" We will measure visits to the Washington Post and Breitbart before and after the Roy Moore controversy as well as visits to pages containing the words "Roy Moore" after the controversy began (we assume all coverage published during the study period after the controversy began at least referenced it). We will consider effects on total webpages visited from mainstream and non-mainstream news and information sources using the criteria described above (we expect that most people will visit at least one website in both categories during the study period and thus exclude a binary measure) and both a binary and count measure for specific behavioral information exposure and search measures (Roy Moore and refugees) using the criteria defined above. Duplicate visits to webpages will not be counted if they are successive (i.e., a page that was reloaded after first opening it). URLs are cleaned of referrer information and other parameters before de-duplication. Statistical analyses All models will be estimated using ordinary least squares with robust standard errors. We will estimate all experimental models in the paper using the control condition as a baseline and present those in the main text or the appendix, but to facilitate reader understanding of placebo versus treatment differences we may report models using the Russia investigation placebo condition as the baseline and excluding the control condition (results will be identical). We will compute the appropriate linear combinations of coefficients to test the relevant hypotheses (e.g., mediaerror-russiaplacebo when the control condition is the excluded category). registration_responses.q24: Yes. This study was approved by the CPHS at Dartmouth (STUDY00030657), the University of Exeter SSIS Ethics Committee (October 27, 2017 [via recognition of Dartmouth's approval]), and the Princeton IRB (IRB# 10239).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: One of the canonical questions in social psychology, political science, and political communication is how persuasion operates. Since the original studies on the effectiveness of mass propaganda (e.g., Lasswell 1938; Smith, Lasswell and Casey 1946), scholars have sought to understand the components of successful persuasive appeals: the identity of the messenger, the contents of the message, and how it is delivered. In the latter category reside all of the classical tools of rhetoric -- figurative language, logical structure, satire -- as well as more recent factors such as the type of medium employed. In this study, we hope to inaugurate a new line of research that returns to these fundamental concerns using cutting-edge methods. Our observation is that one of the most commonly used rhetorical tools, both in political discourse and in everyday discussion, has hardly ever been studied in a systematic manner. That tool is humor. "Humor is the affectionate communication of insight," said Leo Rosten, and anyone who has sought to convince others of their point of view has likely stumbled upon the disarming power of a well-delivered joke. Yet this proverbial arrow in the rhetorical quiver has rarely been subjected to the sort of rigorous scrutiny that other components of the persuasive process have undergone in the research literature. We seek to remedy this oversight with a research program that merges the concerns of political theorists in the deliberative tradition and more recent quantitative research in political communication.

q16.value: H1: The humorous treatment video will cause subjects to be more supportive of gun control, on average, than the serious treatment video. H2: The serious treatment video will cause subjects to be more supportive of gun control, on average, than the placebo video. H3: We are agnostic as to whether the effect of the videos will vary significantly between those initially supportive of or opposed to gun control. H4: The original humorous video will have a greater persuasive effect, and last longer, than the humorous treatment video. H5: The effects of the humorous treatment video will be more likely to persist than the effects of the serious treatment video.

q17.value: Our design is modeled on experimental studies of media effects and persuasion. First, we gather a sample using Amazon's Mechanical Turk. After asking a standard set of demographic and political questions -- including pre-treatment attitudes toward gun control -- we randomly assign subjects to be shown one of four different videos, each approximately 5-6 minutes in length. Two of the videos contain humorous pro-gun-control content, one is a more straightforward, non-humorous version of the gun-control arguments, and finally there is a placebo video about recycling. To measure the dependent variables, subjects are then asked a series of questions about their views on gun policy. We will return to the same set of subjects approximately one week later to test for the persistence of any persuasive effects.

attributes.title: Your life as a refugee: A field experiment with a mobile role-playing game

q1.value: Your life as a refugee: A field experiment with a mobile role-playing game

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: We implement a field experiment targeting attitudes about the refugee crisis. The intervention consists of encouragement to play a mobile role-playing game in which participants make decisions playing the character of a refugee. Based on the psychological theory of perspective taking, we hypothesize that participation in this game can lead to increased support for policies designed to help refugees through shared experiences and empathy.

q16.value: Main hypothesis: Encouragement to use the mobile app leads to more favorable views on policies seeking to help refugees. Secondary hypothesis 1: Encouragement to use the mobile app leads to a reduction of far-right support Secondary hypothesis 2: Encouragement to use the mobile app leads to an increase in the perceived importance of the refugee crisis as a political issue.

q17.value: We specify two analyses: 1. Intent-to-treat analysis: Simple regressions predicting an index of policy attitude with the treatment indicator 2. CACE: IV regressions predicting an index of policy attitude with recalled use of the app (instrumented with the treatment indicator) Note: Secondary DVs are analyzed the same way.
