attributes.title: Fact-checking and Fake News in Election 2016

q1.value: Fact-checking and Fake News in Election 2016

q2.value: Andrew Guess | Brendan Nyhan | Jason Reifler

q5.value: This project received funding from the Poynter Institute (via a grant from the Knight Foundation) and the American Press Institute.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: (Note: This study is a follow-up to a previously preregistered study [EGAP 20151201AA]; some portions of the preregistration are repeated and/or adapted here.) Little is known about why people view political fact­-checking content or whether such content is effective in informing the public. This study will evaluate whether people engage in selective exposure to fact-checking and what effects it has on what they know about politics, which may also vary with their prior political beliefs. Specifically, we examine how nationally representative samples of respondents in the United States select and respond to information from fact-checking websites using a variant of a doubly randomized preference trial (DRPT) design, which allows us to contrast the effects of randomly assigned exposure to fact-­checking with the effects when people have an option to select non­political news instead. This study promises to help us understand when and why people select fact-checks versus other types of information on platforms like Google News (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/13/google-news-fact-check-trump-clinton-us-election) and Medium and on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook. Our study will also include anonymous tracking data on U.S. participants’ online website visits for two weeks before and two weeks after the study. These data, which respondents have already consented to provide anonymously to YouGov as part of their participation in the YouGov Pulse panel, will allow us to determine the real-world prevalence of fact-checking consumption, the conditions under which people are most likely to seek out fact-checks, and the extent of selective exposure to fact-checking. These data will also allow us to measure respondents’ exposure to so-called “fake news” and to assess its prevalence and correlates. In addition, we will be able to examine whether participants assigned to receive fact-checking content are more likely to subsequently seek out such information on their own - an important question for understanding whether reading fact-checks is a habit-forming behavior.

q16.value: H1: Selective exposure We expect that people will not choose to read fact-checks about a favored party as frequently as those about a disfavored party. (We maintain this hypothesis even though our previous study [EGAP 20151201AA] found a preference for reading fact-checks about a preferred candidate. We think those results may not translate for two reasons. First, the ratings in the Italian study were not clearly negative. Second, the US context may simply be different; Italy has a fluid multi-party system compared to a stable two party system where partisan loyalties and identity are stronger, especially in the period immediately before a presidential election.) Like the previous study, the choice question describes the content of the fact-check using a neutral report of a claim made by a candidate. Nonetheless, our specific expectation is that respondents will be more likely to choose to read a fact-check of a statement from a candidate they do not support than a fact-check of a candidate they support. (Unlike in the Italian case, we focus on candidate preference as the directional motivation of interest rather than party.) These effects may vary by political sophistication. Our previous study compared interest in political fact-checks to non-political news. However, that design potentially confounded interest in fact-checks with interest in politics (no political news items were offered that were not fact-checks). We therefore offer respondents a choice between a fact-check of a negative claim about each candidate, a neutral political news item about each candidate that is not a fact-check, and two non-political news items. This design allows us to distinguish selective exposure to fact-checks from interest in news about candidates more generally. Using the Pulse web tracking data, we will further test hypotheses related to selective exposure. First, we will code for whether respondents visited the primary national fact-checking sites - PolitiFact (including its state affiliates), FactCheck.org, and the Washington Post Fact Checker. Previous web tracking data collected by one of the authors (Guess) suggests there will be few visits to fact-checking websites. If there is any period likely to produce traffic to fact-checking websites, it is in the period immediately prior to a presidential election with two relatively unpopular candidates. If there are enough visits to fact-checking websites to analyze, we will create two primary outcome measures: (1) exposure to any fact-checking content (dichotomous) and (2) number of visits to these pages. Depending on data availability, we may augment these measures of exposure to any fact-checking content with measures designed to differentiate between exposure to predisposition-consistent and predisposition-inconsistent content (i.e., coding for whether the fact-check was favorable or unfavorable to Clinton and/or Trump). Finally, we will test whether respondents are disproportionately likely to view "fake news" that is consistent with their political predispositions relative to predisposition-inconsistent "fake news." Descriptive inference: -We will provide the first real-world behavioral estimate of the prevalence of fact-checking consumption during a presidential election campaign. -We will measure the correlation between respondents' self-reports of interest in fact-checking, interest in politics, and political sophistication and their actual fact-check consumption (both dichotomous and count measures). -We will assess whether the article preference measure in our survey instrument correlates with prior web behavior - i.e., whether people who read fact-checks on their own are more likely to select one as an article they'd like to read in our study. (Behavior may differ between a study and the real world; we also anticipate that fact-checking consumption may be relatively rare and we may thus be underpowered to detect this relationship.) -We will measure the prevalence of fake-news consumption in our panel (who sees it, how often, etc.) and how it varies by candidate support and other attitudinal and demographic factors as well as how it varies over time. We may also examine how these measures correspond to results from a post-election survey about recall of and belief in fake news conducted by Buzzfeed and Ipsos. We will then assess the following hypotheses (conditional on past fact-checking consumption being prevalent enough to evaluate its relationship to other factors of interest): Selective exposure: -H1a: We will examine whether there is selective exposure in past fact-check consumption such that people tend to read predisposition-consistent articles and avoid predisposition-inconsistent articles. (We will seek to obtain a prior YouGov measure of candidate preference for our respondents and/or validate the stability of candidate preference in panel data from other sources to account for possible concerns about post-treatment bias. We also plan to conduct an exploratory analysis of how people choose among fact-checks of the two candidates versus political news about them that does not include fact-checks.) -H1b: Respondents will be more likely to choose to read a fact-check of a statement from a candidate they do not support than a fact-check of a candidate they support in our study. -H1c: We will examine whether whether the relationship between candidate preference and past or intended fact-check consumption is moderated by political sophistication. -H1d: Parallel to H1a, we will examine whether people are more likely to read predisposition-consistent articles/pages containing fake news than predisposition-inconsistent fake news. (We define "fake news" as the completely false stories that are increasingly widely circulated online - see below for how we measure this concept.) -H1e: We will examine whether whether the relationship between candidate preference and past fake-news consumption is moderated by political sophistication. H2-H3: Differential learning effects Our design asks people to select the content they are interested in and separately randomizes what content people receive. While we discuss the design in more detail below, key features are necessary to explain our hypotheses. Respondents are assigned to either be randomly exposed to an article regardless of their preference (50%) or to receive the content they prefer (50%). Those who are assigned to be randomly assigned an article are then randomly assigned with equal probability to receive one of six articles (a negative fact-check of Clinton, a negative fact-check of Trump, a political article about Clinton that is not a fact-check, a political article about Trump that is not a fact-check, or one of two non-political articles). On average, we expect that exposure to fact-checks leads to learning about politics, but this effect may vary by respondents' political preferences and be diminished by respondents' ability to select out of fact-check exposure. Thus, our overall expectations are that respondents in the assigned exposure condition who are randomly assigned to a fact-check will have more accurate beliefs about the content of that fact-check than those who are randomly assigned to a non-political article (H2a). We expect the learning effects of randomly assigned fact-check exposure (versus non-political articles) to be lower for counter-attitudinal information than for pro-attitudinal information (H2b). We also expect accuracy of respondent beliefs on a given topic to be lower in the choice condition than when they are assigned to a relevant fact-check (H2c). To understand more precisely how fact-checking exposure affects belief accuracy in the real world, we will test how the effects of exposure to each fact-check vary by candidate preference and which articles people would actually choose to read when given a choice. We expect that each fact-check will be less effective among people who would choose to read it than among those who would not because people who would choose to read a fact-check are likely to be more politically knowledgeable already and therefore will have more accurate beliefs (H3a). We expect fact checks to be more effective among people for whom the fact check is consistent with their candidate preference (H3b). RQ: Habit formation We will also test whether viewing fact-check content affects self-reported attitudes toward fact-checking and subsequent consumption behavior. For subjects in the assigned exposure condition, we will first test whether those who receive fact-checking content view fact-checking more favorably (self-reports of attitudes on our survey). We will also test whether they are more likely to choose to visit a fact-checking website when given the option at the end of the survey and to subsequently visit fact-checking sites on the Internet in on our web tracking data than those who received non-political content (our behavioral measures of interest, which could potentially diverge from attitudinal self-reports).

q17.value: Trial design We adopt a variant of a patient preference trial (PPT) design in which some respondents are randomized to receive a treatment or not and others are allowed to choose their condition (Arceneaux, Johnson, and Murphy 2012; Knox et al. N.d.). In this case, the treatment is exposure to a given fact-check versus other content. Randomization approach We use a simple randomization approach. Respondents are randomly assigned to the article choice condition with 50% probability and to the assigned exposure conditions with 50% probability. An independent randomization assigns each respondent in the assigned exposure to one of six articles with equal probability (1/6). Respondents, data collection and blinding We are conducting this study using a YouGov Pulse panel. We expect this sample, which will take the survey on the YouGov survey platform, to consist of approximately 3,000 people. Respondents are blind to condition. These data, which are completely anonymized, will be collected by the online polling firm YouGov from respondents willing to install tracking software. The online tracking panel is currently branded as YouGov Pulse. Panelists are recruited from YouGov’s traditional participant pool via incentives. The data to be used for this study covers 4 weeks of web traffic from roughly 3,000 respondents. The software tracks web traffic (minus passwords and financial transactions) for all browsers installed on a user's computer and can be uninstalled at any time. Users provide full consent to download and install the software and identifying information is not collected. Interventions and dates of administration The primary intervention is assignment to see one of two fact-checks (assigned treatment), assignment to see one of two political non-fact-check articles (alternative political content), assignment to one of two non-political placebo articles (assigned control), or being given the option to choose which article you would like to read (choice). The study was launched October 22, 2016 by YouGov, which kept it open until they received 3,000 responses (the contracted total). The authors remain blind to the data at the time of the preregistration. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All U.S. residents age 18 or older are eligible to participate. Participants must be members of the YouGov Pulse panel to be selected for inclusion. Primary and secondary outcome measures A primary outcome of interest is whether people express a preference to be exposed to fact-checking content and whether that content is pro- or counter-attitudinal. We measure this outcome through a survey question asking people to say which of six different articles they would like to read. Fact-check: Donald Trump would "engage in a risky scheme to privatize Social Security" Fact-check: Hillary Clinton wants illegal immigrants "collecting Social Security benefits" How Much Is Your Sleep Worth? Why mattresses are the new iPhones The 10 Best (and 5 Worst) Food Developments of the Last 10 Years Netanyahu Meets Trump at Trump Tower Clinton Reaffirms Opposition to UNSC Resolution in Meeting with Netanyahu In addition, we want to assess how much people learn from exposure to fact-checks and whether how much one learns is contingent on choosing exposure. To measure how much one learns from fact-checks, we ask respondents to assess statements related to the content of the fact-checks. These questions are presented below. Both statements were false so responses will be measured on a 1-4 scale where 4=the most accurate and 1=the most inaccurate response. Hillary Clinton would allow illegal immigrants who arrive here to stay and immediately begin to collect Social Security benefits. Donald Trump wants to allow people to put a portion of their Social Security payroll taxes into personal retirement accounts that would be invested in private stocks and bonds. We will also consider how favorable people are towards fact-checking as a secondary outcome measure. The question we will use to measure attitudes towards fact-checking is presented below. We would like to again ask about your views of fact-checking, a new development in journalism that seeks to hold politicians accountable when they make false or misleading statements. In general, how favorable or unfavorable is your overall opinion of the fact-checking movement in journalism? -Very favorable -Somewhat favorable -Slightly favorable -Slightly unfavorable -Somewhat unfavorable -Very unfavorable To verify that respondents read the stimulus articles, they were asked the following questions after seeing a fact-check and given up to three attempts to correctly answer the question before being allowed to proceed. We will analyze passage rates for these questions to ensure that most respondents appeared to have read and understood the articles. [new page - after Kaine fact-check] Which issue was in dispute in the article you just read? (randomize order of choices) -A candidate’s plan for Social Security [correct] -The U.S. budget deficit -Immigration -A candidate’s nominees to the US Supreme Court [new page - after Trump ad fact-check] Which issue was in dispute in the article you just read? (randomize order of choices) -A candidate’s immigration policy [correct] -The war in Libya -A candidate’s jobs program -Health care (Another potential secondary outcome measure we may consider is the time users have spent on each page of the web survey.) Fact-checking consumption will be measured using visits to the three major national fact-checkers - PolitiFact (including state affiliates), Washington Post Fact-Checker, and Factcheck.org. Measures of whether a statement is supported or not by the fact-check and what is pro-Trump/pro-Clinton will be created by coders who are blind to the hypotheses of this study using the ratings of the statements where available, the identities of the speakers, and the text of the article. Fact-checks that are ambiguous about the veracity of the statement (e.g., “Half-true” on PolitiFact) or on the implications of the findings for the two sides in the election will be excluded. If consumption of fact-checking from these websites is extremely rare, we may expand the coding to include visits to fact-checking sites in the United States that were identified by the Duke Reporters’ Lab as active during the election (http://reporterslab.org/fact-checkers-reach-keeps-growing/) and/or to URL identified as fact-checks on Twitter that do not appear on a dedicated fact-checking website. Fake news consumption will be measured using a list of visits to fake news articles identified by Craig Silverman of Buzzfeed as most widely shared on social media before the election (https://www.buzzfeed.com/craigsilverman/viral-fake-election-news-outperformed-real-news-on-facebook?utm_term=.dgjEayPpY#.vwomaLkQD) and shared with the authors. Our procedure for using this list is as follows: Create a list of web domains that posted the fake news articles in the list. Drop any domains that are not strictly “fake news” (excluding YouTube videos posted by “fake news” sites). To determine this, we use the domains identified by Facebook Research as “hard news” via machine learning classification (Bakshy et al. 2015) and remove any domain on this list. Any pages on the resulting list of domains is classified as “fake news” for the purposes of our analysis. Measures of whether a fake news article is favorable or unfavorable to Trump or Clinton will be created by coders who are blind to the hypothesis of this study. Fake news that is ambiguous about the implications for the candidates will be excluded. Statistical analyses We will test our hypothesis on the outcome variables described above by analyzing the average treatment effect of assignment to treatment (typically relative to the appropriate non-political control condition). These models will be estimated using ordinary least squares with robust standard errors. Many of our analyses focus on pro- and counter-attitudinal information and fact-checks, which requires identifying how we will measure pro- and counter-attitudinal. Our general approach is that anything that is consistent with one’s political predispositions is pro-attitudinal, while anything that runs counter to one’s predispositions is counter-attitudinal. We will use candidate choice as our primary way to assess pro- and counter-attitudinal information. When a person says they intend to vote for a major-party candidate, we assume that a fact-check contradicting a claim by their preferred candidate (or supporting a claim by the other candidate) will be considered counter-attitudinal. Similarly, when a person supports a major-party candidate, we assume that a fact-check contradicting a claim by the other candidate (or supporting a claim by their preferred candidate) will be considered pro-attitudinal information. Note that this coding scheme is not mutually exclusive. Some people could see both of the available fact-checks as either pro- or counter-attitudinal. (Given the relative unpopularity of the candidates even among those voting for them, a feeling thermometer may better isolate the subset of respondents who are likely to engage in motivated reasoning [see, e.g., Nyhan, Reifler, and Ubel 2013; Roush N.d.]. For that reason, we may elect to replace candidate choice as our key moderator with feeling thermometers to assess directionally motivated reasoning.) Given that relatively few voters will select a third-party candidate in the vote choice question or say they don’t know who they will support, we will omit this group from our primary results (but will report results including them in an appendix). The omitted category in models below that include a Trump support indicator is thus Clinton support. We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. These include subgroups defined by candidate preference, article preference, political knowledge, etc. (see above). We measure political knowledge using an eight-item additive scale of statements where respondents can say “true”, “false” or “don’t know.” Correct answers will be coded as 1; all others as 0. Notes: For any interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models described below. We will also use indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions with continuous measures and replace those in the models below if it does not. (See Hainmueller et al N.d.) In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible (may not be feasible with the Knox et al. estimator). Don’t know responses will be considered missing data for the accuracy outcome measures. If these are sufficiently common, we will consider coding them at the midpoint of the four-point accuracy scale (2.5). Our preferred knowledge outcome measures are four-point accuracy scales where the most accurate response is “Not accurate at all.” However, if concerns are raised about which response is most accurate, we may consider a binary outcome measure where “Not very accurate” and “Not accurate at all” are coded as 1 and “Very accurate” and “Somewhat accurate” are coded as 0. If feasible, we will implement an estimator designed for a DRPT design instead of or in addition to OLS with robust standard errors (Gaines and Kuklinski 2007; Knox et al. N.d.). We may also use seemingly unrelated regression to increase the efficiency of our estimation for correlated variables. Finally, we may use multinomial regression for the article choice outcome if there is an indication that choice behaviors vary in complex ways that our individual article choice measure does not capture. A pre-test on Mechanical Turk found that 32% of respondents preferred to read a fact-check article among the six offered to respondents in the study. However, if too few respondents on YouGov select fact-checking articles as their preferred content choice, we will instead pool the respondents who selected any political news article (whether fact-checking or not) to increase statistical power. We will pool the respondents in this way if fewer than 10% of respondents select a fact-checking article. In our observational analyses, we will control for the following standard outcome measures in addition to measures of candidate preference and political knowledge: sex (indicator for female), age (indicators for age categories of 30-44, 45-59, and 60+; 18-29 excluded), race (indicator for black) Additional notes: -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our sample as well as measures of respondent attention and comprehension, including both response timing data and accuracy of answers to manipulation check questions about the stimulus articles. -Our primary experimental effect estimates will be unweighted per Franco et al. (N.d.), though we may also report weighted results. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Note: We may estimate models that include a standard set of demographic covariates (indicators for gender, age groups, race, and political knowledge) if including those demographic measures has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models would be reported. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. Regression results for ordered scales constructed from multinomial data will be verified for robustness using multinomial logit or multinomial probit. Regression results for count variables will be verified for robustness using Poisson regression with robust standard errors or negative binomial regression. - As a robustness check, we will use the Pulse tracking data to test whether respondents used search engines to look up answers to any knowledge questions. Relatedly, we may test for correlations between self-reported and actual (as measured by Pulse) knowledge cheating. -Duplicate visits to the same URL will be counted in measures of fact-checking and fake news consumption if they are not successive (i.e., a page that was reloaded after first opening it). -In analyzing the data, we may check if the learning effects of randomly assigned fact-check exposure (versus non-political articles) are higher for people with greater political knowledge or whether learning effects (versus non-political articles) are greater for respondents who read one or more fact-checks (binary measure) in the two weeks prior to the study than those who did not, but do not consider these to be primary hypotheses or research questions of the study. q24.value: Dartmouth CPHS STUDY00029870, NYU IRB IRB-FY2016-1342, Exeter approved under Dartmouth IRB

registration_responses.q1: Fact-checking and Fake News in Election 2016
registration_responses.q2: Andrew Guess | Brendan Nyhan | Jason Reifler
registration_responses.q5: This project received funding from the Poynter Institute (via a grant from the Knight Foundation) and the American Press Institute.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: (Note: This study is a follow-up to a previously preregistered study [EGAP 20151201AA]; some portions of the preregistration are repeated and/or adapted here.) Little is known about why people view political fact­-checking content or whether such content is effective in informing the public. This study will evaluate whether people engage in selective exposure to fact-checking and what effects it has on what they know about politics, which may also vary with their prior political beliefs. Specifically, we examine how nationally representative samples of respondents in the United States select and respond to information from fact-checking websites using a variant of a doubly randomized preference trial (DRPT) design, which allows us to contrast the effects of randomly assigned exposure to fact-­checking with the effects when people have an option to select non­political news instead. This study promises to help us understand when and why people select fact-checks versus other types of information on platforms like Google News (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/13/google-news-fact-check-trump-clinton-us-election) and Medium and on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook. Our study will also include anonymous tracking data on U.S. participants’ online website visits for two weeks before and two weeks after the study. These data, which respondents have already consented to provide anonymously to YouGov as part of their participation in the YouGov Pulse panel, will allow us to determine the real-world prevalence of fact-checking consumption, the conditions under which people are most likely to seek out fact-checks, and the extent of selective exposure to fact-checking. These data will also allow us to measure respondents’ exposure to so-called “fake news” and to assess its prevalence and correlates. In addition, we will be able to examine whether participants assigned to receive fact-checking content are more likely to subsequently seek out such information on their own - an important question for understanding whether reading fact-checks is a habit-forming behavior.
registration_responses.q16: H1: Selective exposure We expect that people will not choose to read fact-checks about a favored party as frequently as those about a disfavored party. (We maintain this hypothesis even though our previous study [EGAP 20151201AA] found a preference for reading fact-checks about a preferred candidate. We think those results may not translate for two reasons. First, the ratings in the Italian study were not clearly negative. Second, the US context may simply be different; Italy has a fluid multi-party system compared to a stable two party system where partisan loyalties and identity are stronger, especially in the period immediately before a presidential election.) Like the previous study, the choice question describes the content of the fact-check using a neutral report of a claim made by a candidate. Nonetheless, our specific expectation is that respondents will be more likely to choose to read a fact-check of a statement from a candidate they do not support than a fact-check of a candidate they support. (Unlike in the Italian case, we focus on candidate preference as the directional motivation of interest rather than party.) These effects may vary by political sophistication. Our previous study compared interest in political fact-checks to non-political news. However, that design potentially confounded interest in fact-checks with interest in politics (no political news items were offered that were not fact-checks). We therefore offer respondents a choice between a fact-check of a negative claim about each candidate, a neutral political news item about each candidate that is not a fact-check, and two non-political news items. This design allows us to distinguish selective exposure to fact-checks from interest in news about candidates more generally. Using the Pulse web tracking data, we will further test hypotheses related to selective exposure. First, we will code for whether respondents visited the primary national fact-checking sites - PolitiFact (including its state affiliates), FactCheck.org, and the Washington Post Fact Checker. Previous web tracking data collected by one of the authors (Guess) suggests there will be few visits to fact-checking websites. If there is any period likely to produce traffic to fact-checking websites, it is in the period immediately prior to a presidential election with two relatively unpopular candidates. If there are enough visits to fact-checking websites to analyze, we will create two primary outcome measures: (1) exposure to any fact-checking content (dichotomous) and (2) number of visits to these pages. Depending on data availability, we may augment these measures of exposure to any fact-checking content with measures designed to differentiate between exposure to predisposition-consistent and predisposition-inconsistent content (i.e., coding for whether the fact-check was favorable or unfavorable to Clinton and/or Trump). Finally, we will test whether respondents are disproportionately likely to view "fake news" that is consistent with their political predispositions relative to predisposition-inconsistent "fake news." Descriptive inference: -We will provide the first real-world behavioral estimate of the prevalence of fact-checking consumption during a presidential election campaign. -We will measure the correlation between respondents' self-reports of interest in fact-checking, interest in politics, and political sophistication and their actual fact-check consumption (both dichotomous and count measures). -We will assess whether the article preference measure in our survey instrument correlates with prior web behavior - i.e., whether people who read fact-checks on their own are more likely to select one as an article they'd like to read in our study. (Behavior may differ between a study and the real world; we also anticipate that fact-checking consumption may be relatively rare and we may thus be underpowered to detect this relationship.) -We will measure the prevalence of fake-news consumption in our panel (who sees it, how often, etc.) and how it varies by candidate support and other attitudinal and demographic factors as well as how it varies over time. We may also examine how these measures correspond to results from a post-election survey about recall of and belief in fake news conducted by Buzzfeed and Ipsos. We will then assess the following hypotheses (conditional on past fact-checking consumption being prevalent enough to evaluate its relationship to other factors of interest): Selective exposure: -H1a: We will examine whether there is selective exposure in past fact-check consumption such that people tend to read predisposition-consistent articles and avoid predisposition-inconsistent articles. (We will seek to obtain a prior YouGov measure of candidate preference for our respondents and/or validate the stability of candidate preference in panel data from other sources to account for possible concerns about post-treatment bias. We also plan to conduct an exploratory analysis of how people choose among fact-checks of the two candidates versus political news about them that does not include fact-checks.) -H1b: Respondents will be more likely to choose to read a fact-check of a statement from a candidate they do not support than a fact-check of a candidate they support in our study. -H1c: We will examine whether whether the relationship between candidate preference and past or intended fact-check consumption is moderated by political sophistication. -H1d: Parallel to H1a, we will examine whether people are more likely to read predisposition-consistent articles/pages containing fake news than predisposition-inconsistent fake news. (We define "fake news" as the completely false stories that are increasingly widely circulated online - see below for how we measure this concept.) -H1e: We will examine whether whether the relationship between candidate preference and past fake-news consumption is moderated by political sophistication. H2-H3: Differential learning effects Our design asks people to select the content they are interested in and separately randomizes what content people receive. While we discuss the design in more detail below, key features are necessary to explain our hypotheses. Respondents are assigned to either be randomly exposed to an article regardless of their preference (50%) or to receive the content they prefer (50%). Those who are assigned to be randomly assigned an article are then randomly assigned with equal probability to receive one of six articles (a negative fact-check of Clinton, a negative fact-check of Trump, a political article about Clinton that is not a fact-check, a political article about Trump that is not a fact-check, or one of two non-political articles). On average, we expect that exposure to fact-checks leads to learning about politics, but this effect may vary by respondents' political preferences and be diminished by respondents' ability to select out of fact-check exposure. Thus, our overall expectations are that respondents in the assigned exposure condition who are randomly assigned to a fact-check will have more accurate beliefs about the content of that fact-check than those who are randomly assigned to a non-political article (H2a). We expect the learning effects of randomly assigned fact-check exposure (versus non-political articles) to be lower for counter-attitudinal information than for pro-attitudinal information (H2b). We also expect accuracy of respondent beliefs on a given topic to be lower in the choice condition than when they are assigned to a relevant fact-check (H2c). To understand more precisely how fact-checking exposure affects belief accuracy in the real world, we will test how the effects of exposure to each fact-check vary by candidate preference and which articles people would actually choose to read when given a choice. We expect that each fact-check will be less effective among people who would choose to read it than among those who would not because people who would choose to read a fact-check are likely to be more politically knowledgeable already and therefore will have more accurate beliefs (H3a). We expect fact checks to be more effective among people for whom the fact check is consistent with their candidate preference (H3b). RQ: Habit formation We will also test whether viewing fact-check content affects self-reported attitudes toward fact-checking and subsequent consumption behavior. For subjects in the assigned exposure condition, we will first test whether those who receive fact-checking content view fact-checking more favorably (self-reports of attitudes on our survey). We will also test whether they are more likely to choose to visit a fact-checking website when given the option at the end of the survey and to subsequently visit fact-checking sites on the Internet in on our web tracking data than those who received non-political content (our behavioral measures of interest, which could potentially diverge from attitudinal self-reports).
registration_responses.q17: Trial design We adopt a variant of a patient preference trial (PPT) design in which some respondents are randomized to receive a treatment or not and others are allowed to choose their condition (Arceneaux, Johnson, and Murphy 2012; Knox et al. N.d.). In this case, the treatment is exposure to a given fact-check versus other content. Randomization approach We use a simple randomization approach. Respondents are randomly assigned to the article choice condition with 50% probability and to the assigned exposure conditions with 50% probability. An independent randomization assigns each respondent in the assigned exposure to one of six articles with equal probability (1/6). Respondents, data collection and blinding We are conducting this study using a YouGov Pulse panel. We expect this sample, which will take the survey on the YouGov survey platform, to consist of approximately 3,000 people. Respondents are blind to condition. These data, which are completely anonymized, will be collected by the online polling firm YouGov from respondents willing to install tracking software. The online tracking panel is currently branded as YouGov Pulse. Panelists are recruited from YouGov’s traditional participant pool via incentives. The data to be used for this study covers 4 weeks of web traffic from roughly 3,000 respondents. The software tracks web traffic (minus passwords and financial transactions) for all browsers installed on a user's computer and can be uninstalled at any time. Users provide full consent to download and install the software and identifying information is not collected. Interventions and dates of administration The primary intervention is assignment to see one of two fact-checks (assigned treatment), assignment to see one of two political non-fact-check articles (alternative political content), assignment to one of two non-political placebo articles (assigned control), or being given the option to choose which article you would like to read (choice). The study was launched October 22, 2016 by YouGov, which kept it open until they received 3,000 responses (the contracted total). The authors remain blind to the data at the time of the preregistration. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All U.S. residents age 18 or older are eligible to participate. Participants must be members of the YouGov Pulse panel to be selected for inclusion. Primary and secondary outcome measures A primary outcome of interest is whether people express a preference to be exposed to fact-checking content and whether that content is pro- or counter-attitudinal. We measure this outcome through a survey question asking people to say which of six different articles they would like to read. Fact-check: Donald Trump would "engage in a risky scheme to privatize Social Security" Fact-check: Hillary Clinton wants illegal immigrants "collecting Social Security benefits" How Much Is Your Sleep Worth? Why mattresses are the new iPhones The 10 Best (and 5 Worst) Food Developments of the Last 10 Years Netanyahu Meets Trump at Trump Tower Clinton Reaffirms Opposition to UNSC Resolution in Meeting with Netanyahu In addition, we want to assess how much people learn from exposure to fact-checks and whether how much one learns is contingent on choosing exposure. To measure how much one learns from fact-checks, we ask respondents to assess statements related to the content of the fact-checks. These questions are presented below. Both statements were false so responses will be measured on a 1-4 scale where 4=the most accurate and 1=the most inaccurate response. Hillary Clinton would allow illegal immigrants who arrive here to stay and immediately begin to collect Social Security benefits. Donald Trump wants to allow people to put a portion of their Social Security payroll taxes into personal retirement accounts that would be invested in private stocks and bonds. We will also consider how favorable people are towards fact-checking as a secondary outcome measure. The question we will use to measure attitudes towards fact-checking is presented below. We would like to again ask about your views of fact-checking, a new development in journalism that seeks to hold politicians accountable when they make false or misleading statements. In general, how favorable or unfavorable is your overall opinion of the fact-checking movement in journalism? -Very favorable -Somewhat favorable -Slightly favorable -Slightly unfavorable -Somewhat unfavorable -Very unfavorable To verify that respondents read the stimulus articles, they were asked the following questions after seeing a fact-check and given up to three attempts to correctly answer the question before being allowed to proceed. We will analyze passage rates for these questions to ensure that most respondents appeared to have read and understood the articles. [new page - after Kaine fact-check] Which issue was in dispute in the article you just read? (randomize order of choices) -A candidate’s plan for Social Security [correct] -The U.S. budget deficit -Immigration -A candidate’s nominees to the US Supreme Court [new page - after Trump ad fact-check] Which issue was in dispute in the article you just read? (randomize order of choices) -A candidate’s immigration policy [correct] -The war in Libya -A candidate’s jobs program -Health care (Another potential secondary outcome measure we may consider is the time users have spent on each page of the web survey.) Fact-checking consumption will be measured using visits to the three major national fact-checkers - PolitiFact (including state affiliates), Washington Post Fact-Checker, and Factcheck.org. Measures of whether a statement is supported or not by the fact-check and what is pro-Trump/pro-Clinton will be created by coders who are blind to the hypotheses of this study using the ratings of the statements where available, the identities of the speakers, and the text of the article. Fact-checks that are ambiguous about the veracity of the statement (e.g., “Half-true” on PolitiFact) or on the implications of the findings for the two sides in the election will be excluded. If consumption of fact-checking from these websites is extremely rare, we may expand the coding to include visits to fact-checking sites in the United States that were identified by the Duke Reporters’ Lab as active during the election (http://reporterslab.org/fact-checkers-reach-keeps-growing/) and/or to URL identified as fact-checks on Twitter that do not appear on a dedicated fact-checking website. Fake news consumption will be measured using a list of visits to fake news articles identified by Craig Silverman of Buzzfeed as most widely shared on social media before the election (https://www.buzzfeed.com/craigsilverman/viral-fake-election-news-outperformed-real-news-on-facebook?utm_term=.dgjEayPpY#.vwomaLkQD) and shared with the authors. Our procedure for using this list is as follows: Create a list of web domains that posted the fake news articles in the list. Drop any domains that are not strictly “fake news” (excluding YouTube videos posted by “fake news” sites). To determine this, we use the domains identified by Facebook Research as “hard news” via machine learning classification (Bakshy et al. 2015) and remove any domain on this list. Any pages on the resulting list of domains is classified as “fake news” for the purposes of our analysis. Measures of whether a fake news article is favorable or unfavorable to Trump or Clinton will be created by coders who are blind to the hypothesis of this study. Fake news that is ambiguous about the implications for the candidates will be excluded. Statistical analyses We will test our hypothesis on the outcome variables described above by analyzing the average treatment effect of assignment to treatment (typically relative to the appropriate non-political control condition). These models will be estimated using ordinary least squares with robust standard errors. Many of our analyses focus on pro- and counter-attitudinal information and fact-checks, which requires identifying how we will measure pro- and counter-attitudinal. Our general approach is that anything that is consistent with one’s political predispositions is pro-attitudinal, while anything that runs counter to one’s predispositions is counter-attitudinal. We will use candidate choice as our primary way to assess pro- and counter-attitudinal information. When a person says they intend to vote for a major-party candidate, we assume that a fact-check contradicting a claim by their preferred candidate (or supporting a claim by the other candidate) will be considered counter-attitudinal. Similarly, when a person supports a major-party candidate, we assume that a fact-check contradicting a claim by the other candidate (or supporting a claim by their preferred candidate) will be considered pro-attitudinal information. Note that this coding scheme is not mutually exclusive. Some people could see both of the available fact-checks as either pro- or counter-attitudinal. (Given the relative unpopularity of the candidates even among those voting for them, a feeling thermometer may better isolate the subset of respondents who are likely to engage in motivated reasoning [see, e.g., Nyhan, Reifler, and Ubel 2013; Roush N.d.]. For that reason, we may elect to replace candidate choice as our key moderator with feeling thermometers to assess directionally motivated reasoning.) Given that relatively few voters will select a third-party candidate in the vote choice question or say they don’t know who they will support, we will omit this group from our primary results (but will report results including them in an appendix). The omitted category in models below that include a Trump support indicator is thus Clinton support. We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. These include subgroups defined by candidate preference, article preference, political knowledge, etc. (see above). We measure political knowledge using an eight-item additive scale of statements where respondents can say “true”, “false” or “don’t know.” Correct answers will be coded as 1; all others as 0. Notes: For any interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models described below. We will also use indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions with continuous measures and replace those in the models below if it does not. (See Hainmueller et al N.d.) In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible (may not be feasible with the Knox et al. estimator). Don’t know responses will be considered missing data for the accuracy outcome measures. If these are sufficiently common, we will consider coding them at the midpoint of the four-point accuracy scale (2.5). Our preferred knowledge outcome measures are four-point accuracy scales where the most accurate response is “Not accurate at all.” However, if concerns are raised about which response is most accurate, we may consider a binary outcome measure where “Not very accurate” and “Not accurate at all” are coded as 1 and “Very accurate” and “Somewhat accurate” are coded as 0. If feasible, we will implement an estimator designed for a DRPT design instead of or in addition to OLS with robust standard errors (Gaines and Kuklinski 2007; Knox et al. N.d.). We may also use seemingly unrelated regression to increase the efficiency of our estimation for correlated variables. Finally, we may use multinomial regression for the article choice outcome if there is an indication that choice behaviors vary in complex ways that our individual article choice measure does not capture. A pre-test on Mechanical Turk found that 32% of respondents preferred to read a fact-check article among the six offered to respondents in the study. However, if too few respondents on YouGov select fact-checking articles as their preferred content choice, we will instead pool the respondents who selected any political news article (whether fact-checking or not) to increase statistical power. We will pool the respondents in this way if fewer than 10% of respondents select a fact-checking article. In our observational analyses, we will control for the following standard outcome measures in addition to measures of candidate preference and political knowledge: sex (indicator for female), age (indicators for age categories of 30-44, 45-59, and 60+; 18-29 excluded), race (indicator for black) Additional notes: -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our sample as well as measures of respondent attention and comprehension, including both response timing data and accuracy of answers to manipulation check questions about the stimulus articles. -Our primary experimental effect estimates will be unweighted per Franco et al. (N.d.), though we may also report weighted results. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Note: We may estimate models that include a standard set of demographic covariates (indicators for gender, age groups, race, and political knowledge) if including those demographic measures has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models would be reported. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. Regression results for ordered scales constructed from multinomial data will be verified for robustness using multinomial logit or multinomial probit. Regression results for count variables will be verified for robustness using Poisson regression with robust standard errors or negative binomial regression. - As a robustness check, we will use the Pulse tracking data to test whether respondents used search engines to look up answers to any knowledge questions. Relatedly, we may test for correlations between self-reported and actual (as measured by Pulse) knowledge cheating. -Duplicate visits to the same URL will be counted in measures of fact-checking and fake news consumption if they are not successive (i.e., a page that was reloaded after first opening it). -In analyzing the data, we may check if the learning effects of randomly assigned fact-check exposure (versus non-political articles) are higher for people with greater political knowledge or whether learning effects (versus non-political articles) are greater for respondents who read one or more fact-checks (binary measure) in the two weeks prior to the study than those who did not, but do not consider these to be primary hypotheses or research questions of the study. attributes.title: Gun Control, Attitude Change, and Bayesian Updating

q1.value: Gun Control, Attitude Change, and Bayesian Updating

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Our study is a two-wave survey experiment that tests two kinds of treatments on attitudes towards gun control.

q16.value: The first treatment, deployed in Wave 1, asks treatment subjects to write a short essay about the arguments they would use to try and persuade those on the opposite side of the gun control debate. We hypothesize that writing such an essay will cause subjects to hold their attitudes more strongly and that those writing essays will exhibit more polarized attitudes than control subjects. In the second wave, subjects will be assigned to read nothing or one of two descriptions of studies between the association between gun control laws and gun-related violence. One study shows a positive relationship while the other shows a negative relationship. Compared to the control condition, we expect that the anti-gun-control treatment (the one showing a positive relationship) will decrease support for gun control laws and that the pro-gun-control treatment will increase it. We do not predict that this effect will be heterogeneous, nor do we expect that this effect will interact with the essay treatment from Wave 1.

attributes.title: The Rule, Not the Exception: Bayesian Reasoning in Contentious Environments

q1.value: The Rule, Not the Exception: Bayesian Reasoning in Contentious Environments

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The design of this experiment is motivated by previous work in which subjects were uniformly shown to update their beliefs in the direction of the evidence presented to them. This pattern of parallel updating is consistent with a Bayesian framework and not consistent with the attitude polarization prediction in the motivated reasoning literature. A recurring criticism of our previous experiments is that the *conditions* for motivated reasoning may not have been present. This new experiment will address this criticism by randomizing some hypothesized conditions for motivated reasoning.

q16.value: Under Bayesian reasoning, the conditions are unimportant: the subjects in the pro treatments will report higher values on both dependent variables than subjects in the con treatments. Under Motivated reasoning, the conditions will trigger ""defensive"" information processing and will create negative effects, i.e., subjects in the pro treatments will report lower values than subjects in the con treatments.

q17.value: Tests are described in full in attached pdf.

q21.value: We have conducted a variant of this study before, so we understand the sample size requirements.

attributes.title: Lord, Ross, and Lepper Replication and Extension

q1.value: Lord, Ross, and Lepper Replication and Extension

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Lord, Ross, and Lepper (1979) presented the results of a laboratory demonstration that purported to show that subjects, when confronted with mixed evidence, both assimilate information in a biased manner and become polarized in their attitudes. Our purpose in replicating their findings is twofold: first, we hope to demonstrate that the patterns of behavior measured in the late 1970s among a student population continue to obtain among an adult sample in 2014. Second, we will extend the original design to manipulate the information content of the evidence in order to estimate the effects of mixed evidence on attitudes, as opposed to one-sided or null evidence.

q16.value: Attitude polarization in the face of conflicting evidence (see design document)

q17.value: See document; difference in means with and without covariate adjustment

attributes.title: Effectiveness of dry needling for knee pain
attributes.description:
Frequent knee pain affects approximately 25% of adults, limits function and mobility, and impairs quality of life. There are many causes of and treatments for knee pain, typical causes of knee pain in adults: osteoarthritis; patellofemoral pain syndrome; and meniscal, tendon, and ligament injuries.

Nonsurgical management of knee pain has been supported for common knee diseases. 

No previous systematic review about the dry needling's role in the management of knee pain has been published.

q2.value: Dry needling alone or as an adjunct with other interventions is effective on pain and related-disability in individuals with knee pain

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We realized a systematic review and meta-analysis. 

The following databases were searched in PubMed, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PEDro, Scopus and Web of Sciences. Clinical trials that had been in Spanish or English. Any restrictions in dates frame.

The question may be defined using PICO question:
- Population: Knee pain
- Intervention: dry needling OR intramuscular stimulation
- Comparison: sham OR placebo OR control OR intervention
- Outcome: pain OR disability OR function

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The following data were extracted from the included studies: (1) bibliographic details: authors and year of publication; (2) demographics: number of participants, age and gender; (3) clinical information: musculoskeletal knee disorder diagnosis, disease duration, clinical pain intensity, intervention characteristics and outcome measures (e.g., visual analog scale [VAS], numeric rating scale [NRS], disability).

q11.value: We analyzed all studies that we will be able to include and provide sufficient data to meta-analyze

question.value:
- Pain intensity: any outcome to measure the pain intensity (e.g., visual analogue scale, numeric rating scale...)
- Disability: any outcome to measure the disability or function of the patients (e.g., WOMAC, Kujala...).

The data of the articles included will be used to realize a quantitative analysis. The mean diference (MD) between groups will be converted to standardized means difference (SMD), with a 95% confidence interval (CI). A random-effects model was used to determine the overall effect size: in SMD an effect size of 0.8 or greater was considered large, between 0.5 to 0.8 as moderate and between 0.2 to 0.5 as small, and p-values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant. The heterogeneity of the studies will be assessed using the I² statistic. The Cochrane group has established the following interpretation of the I² statistic: 0-30% may not be relevant 0–30% may not be relevant; 30–60% presents moderate heterogeneity, and greater than 60% may represent substantial heterogeneity. The asymmetry was evaluated using a funnel plot in those analyses formed by at least five studies, which indicates the possible risk of publication of small studies with negative results. Studies were analyzed using the Review Manager 5.3 statistical software

Meta-analyses were done according to the follow up (short-, mid- and long-term follow-up). We realized subgroups depending on the knee diagnosis.

q23.value: Risk of bias and methodological quality were assessed by two authors. Randomized controlled clinical trials were evaluated with the Cochrane Collaboration tool for assessing the risk of bias. Additionally, the PEDro scale score was used to assess the methodological quality of the included studies. A score greater than or equal to 5 is considered to have high methodological quality
